title: Can an individual organism evolve? - Quora

response.answer_text: Can an individual organism evolve? In everyday use of the word "evolve"we all evolve over our lifetimes. But not in the Darwinian sense of the theory of evolution by natural selection. Evolution is about individuals in a population out competing one another in the environment where they live. The best adapted ones are more successful in reproducing and passing on genes. The basic ingredients needed for Darwinian Evolution are Reproduction with heritable traits.Variation of heritable traits within a population, where new variations occasionally appear due to incidental reproduction errors (mutations).Selection pressures causing differences in reproduction rates, for the different variations in the traits.The words I put in bold show why an individual cannot evolve. It can not happen during the lifetime of an individual, the point where heritable information (DNA) is passed to the next generation is key to the process. We need a population with variation. An individual is no population and has no variation. Difference in reproductive success drive the whole process. It happens because of the differences between individuals in a population. We cannot have that with just one individual.

A single organism can not evolve, at least not in biological jargon. Biological evolution describes the changes in a population of organisms caused by the accumulation of inheritable variation. A single organism can develop. I conjecture that the word ‘develop’ in biological jargon corresponds to your meaning of the word ‘evolve’. A child ‘develops’ in to an adult. A child does not evolve into an ‘adult’. An embryo develops into a baby. The embryo does not evolve into a baby. A population of extant birds evolved from a non avian dinosaur. The population of extant birds did not develop from a non avian dinosaur. There are some borderline situations where both words may be applicable. We now know that cancer cells both develop AND evolve from somatic cells. It is hard to pin down. The cancer cells are arguably part of a single organism from which it emerged. Yet a cancer cell is in some ways an individual organism itself. I sometimes use the word ‘emerge’ for those borderline cases.

It depends upon which meaning of ‘evolve/evolution’ you are using. If you mean Evolution by Natural Selection, then no because that happens on populations rather than individuals. If you just mean can people evolve in the colloquial sense of changing, then sure. Evolution by natural selection needs a population where: - Individuals differ - Differences are inherited - Individuals produce more offspring than the environment can support Given those things, we expect that over time those individuals best suited to survive in their environment will continue to reproduce and those least suited will eventually die out. There are a lot of questions here on Evolution and it would seem that many are targeted at poking holes in Evolutionary Theory. Anybody who actually understands Evolution would realize that the fundamental theory is simply a statement of empirical facts and hence could only be overturned if those facts were falsified. It is hard to imagine a coherent universe where those facts could actually be falsified. You can see those three facts above in two generations of Maple trees. Beyond its simple roots, Evolution can become incredibly complex and it is certain that there are disagreements and misunderstandings as to which mechanisms are most important in particular cases. Discovering that some particular mechanism thought to be important is not that important does not invalidate the Theory of Evolution any more than a mistaken theory of chemical mechanisms for a type of reaction invalidates the Periodic table of the Elements.

Not in the biological definition of the term. Individuals can grow, and then they survive (or dcon’t) and reproduce (or don’t). But eventually, all individuals will die. Populations can evolve, as a given trait becomes more common or less common. But each individual has the traits that s/he has. Pokemon, Lamarck, the X-Men, and creationists claim that evolution is about one organism “magically” turning into something different, but that’s not how actual biological evolution works. An individual either survives and reproduces (in which case the next generation includes copies of those traits that made survival and reproduction possible) or it doesn’t. As soon as someone asks you for an example of one individual “evolving” into another, you can automatically dismiss them, because they have no idea how the process works, and they are arguing against a figment of their imagination. Hope that helps.

Yes, though not via natural selection and accidental gene damage. Natural evolution of human beings and probably many other organisms will soon cease to matter thanks to the gene-editing abilities of CRISPR and future genetic engineering technologies. CRISPR-edited genes are already used in combatting certain medical conditions so we can say the treated person “evolved” a better set of genes. With enough accumulated changes to an individual over their lifetime, especially if that lifetime is massively extended by genetic engineering, we might see an individual organism substantially different from what it started out as.

To clarify: are you asking if say you as an individual, might be able to change on a physiological level in adaptation to an environmental pressure (maybe you get more muscular because you have to lift heavy stuff), and have that change pass down through your genes? The answer to that question would be no. Individuals may adapt their physiology to the extent that the ability is genetically encoded, but only species can evolve.

Because that’s not part of the definition of evolution. Evolution works on populations and not individuals. The theory of Evolution describes how a given mutation might increase within a population or die out depending on the selection pressures.

An individual organism is born with a genetic code that gives it certain characteristics. It is done and settled. That organism can not get better from some mutation that gives it an advantage. Evolution happens if that fixed and settled organism reproduces (sexually or not) to produce offspring with a mutation in its germ line (the pass along genes that will go to its offspring). If that mutation has no effect at the time, or confers an advantage the line has evolved. In most cases the mutation is deleterious and the line dies out.

Remember, the word evolve has several connotations. One, is simply how we change over the course of our life. If you specify that THAT is the meaning you are thinking of, we CAN evolve. Another connotation is evolution by natural selection, and that only happens to populations over generations. After all, it requires changing alleles over time.

Because we die with the same alleles (forms of genes) that we are born with. Evolution is “descent with modification”. Individuals cannot change tbeir genetic makeup, but over generations a population can have their genetics changed by natural selection. IOW, an allele can spread from 1 individual in generation to all individuals in generation n (the exact number of generations varies with selection pressure) this happens because the individual with the allele has more children than thise without the allele, and the children inherit the allele. Then those children have more children than those without the allele, etc etc. Over generations eventually everyone is descended from that first individual. So now the entire population has an allele it did not have before. Thus polulations can change, but individuals cannot

An individual can and does evolve. It’s just not important until it reproduces. Germ line cells mutate, so an individual ovum or sperm can have 50–100 new mutations. That’s evolution. But, no individual is immortal, and once it dies none of the germ line mutations exist anymore… …unless it has reproduced!

Natural selection is defined as differential rates of reproduction in a population of organisms. An individual organism cannot evolve because it is not a population. The notion of an individual organism evolving is an oxymoron.
No. Mutation can occur in an individual, but evolution is what happens to a population.
Evolution is represented by changes in allele frequencies in the gene pool which is a generational effect.
